newsitem.title: SPAIN: One year later, Spain's PP wins praise for economy.
newsitem.headline: One year later, Spain's PP wins praise for economy.

text.p: On the eve of its election victory one year ago, Spain's conservative Popular Party government won praise for what it considers one of its most glittering accomplishments -- an economic renaissance.

According to a new quarterly survey published on Sunday in the newspaper El Pais, a sizeable majority of Spanish businessman said the government was doing a good job managing the economy, which should continue to improve this year.
Nine out of 10 businessmen polled said the economy would pick up in the next 12 months, and they applauded the government's role -- with 59 percent categorising its performance as good or very good.

Last year, the Popular Party formed a minority government in May after winning the March 3 general election and promptly launched an economic clean-up to ensure it could meet its European goal of helping found the common currency in 1999.
To participate in the Euro's launch, Spain must adhere to strict criteria on inflation, long-term interest rates, currency and deficit and debt levels.

Sweeping aside 13 years of Socialist rule, the PP government pressed ahead with classic elements of conservative economic management, tightening the nation's fiscal strings and inaugurating a string of liberalisation members.
A drop in inflation and interest rates, a stable peseta, and a new, confident atmosphere have been the reward.
"We have given a lesson on how to make changes and how to accept changes," crowed Economy Minister Rodrigo Rato at an appearance on Saturday to commemorate the election victory.
At a separate appearance, Industry Minister Josep Pique beat the government's drum even more loudly.

"A year ago no one believed that we would be able to fulfil in such a clear fashion the conditions necessary to join the third phase of European Economic and Monetary Union from the start," Pique said.

Inflation fell to 2.9 percent in January, its lowest rate in 28 years and well beneath the 3.9 percent of a year earlier. Spain's key short-term interest rate has declined to a historic low of six percent, down from nine percent at the start of 1996.
The government has also pledged to reduce the deficit to three percent of gross domestic product in 1997, as required, from 4.4 percent in 1996 and 6.6 percent in 1995.
Despite the improvement, not everything is rosy on the economic front.
According to the poll, the government's key challenges were labour reform, a reduction in expenditure and in unemployment and fiscal reform.
Labour and employer representatives are in talks to make Spain's rigid labour market more flexible.
Spain still sports western European's highest unemployment rate -- at 21.78 percent near double the European Union average.
On Saturday, vice president Francisco Alvarez Cascos pledged 200,000 net new jobs this year as well as a reduction in unemployment to two million from the current 2.26 million registered unemployed.
